images.caption: Figure 1:Overview of our core contributions. We identify the trade-off between accuracy and throughput for systems that require verifying a large number of programs. Through a generate-prune-then-rank strategy, we show that the trade-off can be improved. By filtering candidates with a weak verifier, the ORM can then rank more accurately than the ORM alone and efficiently compared to the strongest verifier.

Figure 2:Trade-off curves for the 14B generator. The colors represent different ranking strategies, while the markers represent different pruning methods. “Majority Voting” is the verifier-only setup where we use majority voting to select the best candidate after pruning with the weak verifier. We report the full results inAppendix Iand other model curves inAppendix H.

Figure 3:Distribution of failed candidates based onVθsubscript𝑉𝜃V_{\theta}{}italic_V start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_θ end_POSTSUBSCRIPTrank. A rank of 1 means the candidate was the top-ranked, while 128 means it was the lowest-ranked. The rows are the individual verifiers while the columns are the datasets. This is for the 1.5BVθsubscript𝑉𝜃V_{\theta}italic_V start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_θ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. The graph for the 500MVθsubscript𝑉𝜃V_{\theta}italic_V start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_θ end_POSTSUBSCRIPTis inFigure 6.

header: Appendix GIs using a causal language model head with pairwise losses the best approach?

images.caption: Figure 4:Results from training a 1.5B ORM with different objectives.

Figure 5:Trade-off curves for CodeContests when using the 3B generator. The colors represent different ranking strategies, while the markers represent different pruning methods. “Majority Voting” is the verifier-only setup where we use majority voting to select the best candidate after pruning with the weak verifier. We report the full results inAppendix I.

Figure 6:Distribution of the failed candidates based on whereVθsubscript𝑉𝜃V_{\theta}{}italic_V start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_θ end_POSTSUBSCRIPThad ranked them. A rank of 1 means the candidate was the top-ranked, while 128 means it was the lowest-ranked. The rows are the individual verifiers while the columns are the datasets.
